Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-level Response Diversity: Land Use, Livelihood Diversification, and Resilience in Northern Tanzania

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Paul Leslie (Carolina Population Center, the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill) and Dr. J. Terrence McCabe (University of Colorado) will undertake research on how variation in household and community responses to environmental changes and policy constraints affect the overall resilience of socio-ecological systems, and the role of cultural institutions in those systems. Data to develop models to explore these issues will be collected in Tanzania. Throughout much of East Africa, traditionally nomadic and semi-nomadic herders have been adopting agriculture and engaging in labor migration. The environmental and social consequences of these changes are likely to be profound but remain poorly understood. This project will clarify the causes of the changing land use and livelihood patterns, and will explore how these changes affect the social-ecological system, including the viability of households and communities and the impacts on land cover and biodiversity. A particular focus will be response diversity. Response diversity results from the fact that not all actors (individuals, households, communities) respond the same way to changing conditions; the variation in response may be more important than the typical or average response in understanding the effects of decision making under changing conditions.

The project is innovative in its integration of empirical field-based research with agent-based modeling (ABM), a computer simulation technique that is well-suited to studying complex systems in which households and communities interact with one another and make decisions influenced by changing conditions. Used together, these methods will reveal much about how land use, livelihoods, family demography, population growth and other factors respond to changes in the physical and political-economic environment, especially unpredictable fluctuations and shocks that test overall system resilience. Shocks can be climatic (e.g., severe droughts), biotic (e.g., livestock disease epidemics), and sociopolitical (e.g., loss of access to pasture and other resources when conservation areas are established).

The scientific significance of this research lies in its contribution to understanding and theorizing the very complex effects of response diversity on socio-ecological resilience. The research results will have a direct bearing on conservation and development in East Africa and will also help to understand changing socio-ecological systems elsewhere. The researchers' findings also will suggest ways of mitigating the potentially negative impacts of social and ecological change on human well-being while also promoting effective conservation and development measures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout much of East Africa, peoples traditionally dependent on nomadic or semi-nomadic livestock herding have been adopting agriculture and engaging in labor migration. The environmental and social consequences of these shifts are likely to be profound yet the processes involved remain poorly understood.  The central aim of this project has been to clarify the causes of the changing land use and livelihood patterns of Maasai people living in northern Tanzania, and to explore how these changes are likely to affect the social-ecological system, including the well-being of households and communities and the implications for biodiversity and wildlife conservation. Because of the presence of numerous national parks and protected areas, and the abundant, iconic wildlife, this is a region that is of special interest from the perspective of wildlife conservation, tourism, and the Tanzanian national economy.  A particular focus is on the role that response diversity plays in shaping the consequences of changing livelihoods and land use. Response diversity results from the fact that not all actors (individuals, households, communities) respond the same way to changing conditions; the variation in response may be more important than the typical or average response.  The project integrates empirical field-based research with agent-based modeling (ABM), a computer simulation technique that is well suited to studying complex systems in which actors or entities such as households or communities interact and make decisions influenced by changing conditions. 

Our research results thus far indicate that changing livelihood patterns have in large part been due to changes in access to land and how the available land is used at both household and village scales. Especially important are issues concerning: how villages are allocating land to households; how some individuals and outside organizations have gained access to large land holdings; and how livelihoods have diversified as Maasai have begun to adopt agriculture and engage in labor migration.  Access to land has emerged as a driving force in this social-ecological system – a problem exacerbated by population growth, fragmentation due to the formation of new households and the splitting of villages, and by the establishment of a large commercial ranch and conservation efforts.  Environmental fluctuations – especially unpredictable rainfall patterns and long term drought, but also concerns over livestock disease epidemics – also play an important role in shaping the evolving livelihood strategies.

 

We also examined the process of migration, which includes migration of young men to work as guards in urban areas and migration of both young and older men to become middlemen in the tanzanite gem trade.  The latter is potentially quite lucrative, and in some areas is driving changes in land use (e.g., by generating sufficient earnings to allow families to buy tractors and expand farms), local political leadership, and possibly economic stratification.

Ongoing experimentation with the agent-based model allows further exploration of the interactions among the social and ecological components of the social-ecological system in the study area and similar systems. It will thus enable evaluation of possible further changes in livelihood mixes and rules (traditional practices or government policies) concerning land use and access to resources.

We have presented the results of our research at major national conferences and in university settings. Publications resulting from this project have appeared in a variety of scientific journals and have contributed both theoretically and empirically to the discipline. This project has provided training opportunities for graduate students at the University of Colorado, the University of North Carolina, and the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania
